content.raw:
Yeah, the reason I suggested using shadow-fixed generally is so that we can make sure to catch things before they get sent out publicly. If there's an issue in shadow-fixed we can just roll back an errant release causing regressions.  If it isn't caught until after the sync, we either have to do a hurry up fixup release and accelerated QA and resync or it's broken for a full cycle. 

On the ROS farm we test everything against shadow-fixed. That way we know before we sync that everything is happy. If it passed in shadow-fixed we're confident that after syncing it to public it will stay working.
